Making Tensorflow and friends use the Mac GPU

Making Tensorflow and friends use the Mac GPU

This works on Apple Silicon and, to my pleasant surprise, with AMD GPUs on Intel MacPros.

This is a good reference apple developer site that I used.

  1. Install miniforge for macos arm https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-arm64.sh

    $ bash Miniforge3-MacOSX-arm64.sh

  2. Tell Conda recognize pip-installed packages (useful later)

    $ conda config --set pip_interop_enabled true

  3. Create a new conda environment you'll set all this stuff up in and make it the active environment:

    $ conda create -n tensorflow python=3.9
$ conda activate tensorflow
(tensorflow) $

  4. Build numpy from source:

    (tensorflow) $ cd ~/src
(tensorflow) $ git clone https://github.com/numpy/numpy
(tensorflow) $ cd numpy
(tensorflow) $ cp site.cfg.example site.cfg
(tensorflow) $ cat >> site.cfg
[accelerate]
libraries = Accelerate, vecLib
^d
# For the time being, build version 1.21 which seems to be what makes tensorflow happy
(tensorflow) $ git checkout main/1.21.x # from memory, think that's right
(tensorflow) $ export NPY_LAPACK_ORDER=accelerate
(tensorflow) $ python setup.py build
[...]
(tensorflow) $ python setup.py install

# install ipython, verify numpy built with acceleration

(tensorflow) $ conda install ipython
(tensorflow) $ ipython
Python 3.9.10 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Feb  1 2022, 21:25:34)
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 8.0.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.

In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: np.show_config()
blas_mkl_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
blis_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
openblas_info:
    libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas']
    library_dirs = ['/opt/local/lib']
    language = c
    define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)]
blas_opt_info:
    libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas']
    library_dirs = ['/opt/local/lib']
    language = c
    define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)]
accelerate_info:
    extra_compile_args = ['-I/System/Library/Frameworks/vecLib.framework/Headers']
    extra_link_args = ['-Wl,-framework', '-Wl,Accelerate']
    define_macros = [('NO_ATLAS_INFO', 3), ('HAVE_CBLAS', None)]
lapack_opt_info:
    extra_compile_args = ['-I/System/Library/Frameworks/vecLib.framework/Headers']
    extra_link_args = ['-Wl,-framework', '-Wl,Accelerate']
    define_macros = [('NO_ATLAS_INFO', 3), ('HAVE_CBLAS', None)]
Supported SIMD extensions in this NumPy install:
    baseline = NEON,NEON_FP16,NEON_VFPV4,ASIMD
    found = ASIMDHP,ASIMDDP
    not found =

In [3]:
Do you really want to exit ([y]/n)? y

  5. Now ready to install tensorflow

    (tensorflow) $ conda install -c apple tensorflow-deps
(tensorflow) $ python -m pip install tensorflow-macos
(tensorflow) $ python -m pip install tensorflow-metal

  6. Probably want to install jupyter, matplotlib, etc with conda as well.

  7. For the sake of tensorflowhub may need to build numpy @ 1.22. This breaks tensorflow which wants 1.21.n So have to alter the tensorflow-deps json file in the miniforge tree -

    Look in

    ~/miniforge3/envs/tensorflow/conda-meta/tensorflow-deps-2.8.0-0.json

    Change numpy config line to something like

    "numpy >=1.21.2,<1.23",

    Rebuild numpy as above.

  8. install tensorflowhub with pip not conda
